diagnoses.name: Early pregnancy loss
diagnoses.details: Spontaneous loss of a pregnancy before the 20th week. Approximately 10% to 20% of known pregnancies end in miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Ectopic pregnancy
diagnoses.details: A pregnancy in which the fertilized egg implants outside the uterus. Can cause severe pain and bleeding in early pregnancy, sometimes mistaken for miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Gestational trophoblastic disease
diagnoses.details: A group of rare tumors that involve abnormal growth of cells inside a woman's uterus. Can produce symptoms similar to pregnancy, including miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Urinary tract infection (UTI)
diagnoses.details: An infection in any part of the urinary system. While it primarily causes urinary symptoms, severe or untreated UTI can lead to systemic symptoms and possibly impact pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.details: Mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. Can manifest as decreased appetite and obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety disorders
diagnoses.details: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant anxiety or fear. Obsessive-compulsive behaviors are a hallmark of some anxiety disorders.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine disorders
diagnoses.details: Disorders of the endocrine system, such as thyroid disorders, can cause a wide range of symptoms including changes in mood, appetite, and possibly miscarriage.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional deficiencies
diagnoses.details: Deficiencies in essential vitamins and minerals can impact overall health, leading to issues like dysgeusia (distortion of the sense of taste), decreased appetite, and potentially complicate pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Chronic kidney disease
diagnoses.details: Chronic kidney disease can lead to a buildup of wastes in the body, impacting various systems and causing symptoms like decreased appetite, among others.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.details: A hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with small cysts on the outer edges. It's associated with hormonal imbalances that can affect fertility and might increase the risk of miscarriage.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin D deficiency can cause bone pain and weakness due to insufficient calcium absorption. It may not directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, pallor, or interstitial cystitis but can contribute to overall poor health, potentially exacerbating these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to bone pain and pallor due to anemia and mineral and bone disorder. It doesn't directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, or interstitial cystitis but affects overall health significantly.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: Anemia, particularly iron-deficiency anemia, can cause pallor and may be related to chronic diseases that can cause symptoms like bone pain. It does not directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, or interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain and can be associated with fatigue and sleep, memory, and mood issues. It doesn't directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, or interstitial cystitis but can coexist with these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis can cause pseudoseizures due to lesions in the brain. It is also associated with pain, including bone pain, but does not directly cause bronchitis, pallor, or interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause a wide array of symptoms including bone pain and pallor due to anemia. It can also cause seizures but does not directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, or interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Psychogenic Non-Epileptic Seizures (PNES)
diagnoses.description: PNES, also known as pseudoseizures, are seizures that occur without a neurological basis and are associated with psychological conditions. They do not directly cause bronchitis, bone pain, pallor, or interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet, and can cause bone pain. While it doesn't directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, pallor, or interstitial cystitis, it affects overall health.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Leukemia can cause bone pain and pallor due to anemia. While it doesn't directly cause pseudoseizures, bronchitis, or interstitial cystitis, the systemic nature of leukemia affects the entire body.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: COPD can lead to chronic bronchitis, one of the symptoms described. It does not directly cause pseudoseizures, bone pain, pallor, or interstitial cystitis but can contribute to overall diminished health.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. It can lead to an increased risk of clotting events, enlarged spleen, and problems due to increased blood viscosity. Polycythemia can contribute to a feeling of fullness or discomfort in the abdomen, which might be related to gastroesophageal reflux symptoms or splenomegaly.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic blood cancer where progressive scarring or fibrosis of the bone marrow occurs, disrupting the body's normal production of blood cells. This can lead to anemia, weakness, fatigue, and an enlarged spleen. It may cause symptoms such as early satiety and could indirectly relate to gastroesophageal reflux.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in certain blood-forming cells of the bone marrow. It can lead to an increased number of white blood cells, including monocytes, and can cause fatigue, night sweats, and an enlarged spleen.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body produces too many platelets, leading to a risk of blood clots and bleeding. It shares some symptoms with polycythemia vera and can cause headaches, dizziness, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs when there is not enough iron in the body, leading to reduced production of red blood cells. It can lead to fatigue, weakness, and can indirectly affect attention and cognitive functions.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland is underactive and produces insufficient hormones. This can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, weight gain, and possibly affecting reproductive health, thereby potentially contributing to infertility.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, leading to symptoms such as bloating, diarrhea, and anemia, which can indirectly affect fertility and attention through nutritional deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease in which stomach acid or, occasionally, stomach content, flows back into your esophagus, which can irritate the lining of your esophagus and lead to recurrent heartburn, chest pain, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
diagnoses.description: A neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by patterns of attention difficulty, hyperactivity, and impulsiveness that are not appropriate for a person's age. It can affect personal, academic, and professional life.

diagnoses.name: Stress
diagnoses.description: While not a disease, chronic stress can exacerbate or contribute to a variety of health problems, including gastrointestinal issues like GERD, mental health issues like attention deficit, and potentially indirectly affecting fertility through hormonal imbalances.

diagnoses: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) Secondary to another condition
Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Rheumatoid Arthritis, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
Gastrointestinal disorders causing vomiting and allergic-like reactions (e.g., celiac disease or inflammatory bowel disease)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Gastrointestinal allergies (e.g., food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome)
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS, also known as Lou Gehrig's Disease)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can be either non-cancerous (benign) or cancerous (malignant), primary, or secondary. Common symptoms include headaches, seizures, problems with vision, vomiting, and mental changes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) affects the central nervous system and can cause symptoms such as fatigue, walking difficulties, numbness, muscle spasticity, and cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. It's often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraines are a type of headache characterized by intense, throbbing pain often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Some people also experience aura, which can affect vision.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus that develops in response to an infection or trauma. Symptoms can include headache, fever, weakness, seizures, and changes in behavior or consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Cerebral vasculitis is inflammation of the blood vessel walls in the brain or spine. It can cause headaches, seizures, strokes, and cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain. Causes can include viral infection and immune system abnormality. Symptoms may include headache, fever, confusion, seizures, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia Gravis is a chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disorder that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A brain aneurysm is a bulge in a blood vessel in the brain that can leak or rupture, causing bleeding into the brain (hemorrhagic stroke). Symptoms may include a sudden, severe headache, neck pain, nausea, and blurred vision.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Hepatitis B and C Related Cryoglobulinemia
